reviews.review_text: It was down to the three of us.  'I'm the executioner,' I stated quickly, with a confidence that cracked at its edges. A mask confidence, stuck to my face with the sinuous yellow terror of a hunted animal.  Tiny Box Tim claimed the same. But I had built up a rapport with the medium, and the dead were similarly deceived.  When we put him on the scaffold, he was calm. His defense came too slowly: 'But  I'm  the executioner,' he complained. A quick and uncovering apology.  'We can't both be,' I hissed. The medium's vote wavered.  And he damned us as we dropped him and our judgment broke like his own weight against his neck.  'Town wins!' I said, mocking, hysterical. The con was over. And as we turned to our beds I fondled the long knives in my pocket and wished the medium sweet dreams. She would be with her communicants in the grey and severed world beyond the scaffold soon enough.

Town of Salem is a Strategic Elimination game that's set the the town of, well, Salem, back when the witch trials were very much alive.  This was a browser game in the past for quite some time, but December 15th is when it's mark on Steam came along. I played the browser version pretty extensively, and it's a very fun game to play because the outcome solely depends on player interaction and decisions.  See, you have these various roles, all with different alliances. Townies try and work together to survive and find out who the bad guys are. The mafia are their own group, trying to eliminate anyone who isn't them. And then the neutrals are people trying to achieve their own goal, neither with townies nor mafia. 15+ roles exist in the game, and they can all have a huge outcome on any game.  What's the catch? You have no idea who is what, so you need to use your smarts and think about whether to trust the people you're with or not. Each day, there's a discussion, then there's voting. If one person is voted to be lynched, they have a chance to defend themselves, then the town decides whether that person is guilty or innocent. The game then transitions to night, where the action happens. People can be stabbed, moved, killed, distracted, just about anything can happen at night, as careful as you may be. The game ends when either the Townies or Mafia wins (Neutrals are rare cases.)  This is why I like this game so much. Like I said, it depends heavily on human interaction, which is what keeps every game fresh and alive. You're always given a random role at the start of a new game. You can pick classic mode where there's a set list of roles, and all 15 players fufill one, or you can do 'All Any' where you don't know what roles exist, and that makes it an even bigger mystery.  Overall, Town of Salem is an awesome game to play just for the suspensefulness and the fresh variety with every game, I really recommend this game.

Worst playerbase I have ever seen. People on skype calls cooperating while being on opposing teams. People completely arbitrarily helping someone who is supposed to be their enemy, even when they have a good chance of winning. People refusing to learn most basic and essential mechanics (wills, invest clues). Almost every game, 2-3 people leave right at the start.  Perhaps it's different in ranked. However, I've been unable to join any ranked games. Client disconnects after about 30 seconds of staying on home screen without joining any games (some culling of inactive connections, I presume - just have to restart for it to work again) - not an issue in non-ranked play, but queues for ranked are long enough for disconnection to occur, so it can never join a lobby. Might just be a very specific issue only I have, idk.  The game itself is quite good and can be a lot of fun, but not with such a playerbase. I hoped it would get better some time after launch, when those who have more interest in trolling and derping around than in the actual game quit, but nope. Still the same, perhaps even worse.  It's still recommended if you have enough friends with some free time to play only with them. But not otherwise. Unless you just want to annoy and grief people or enjoy that being done to you.

Where do i start with this magnificent game? Well, here i guess. Town of Salem is a simplistic game where you click and type, easy right? If you said yes, you're wrong. This game is all about deceiving others, figuring out others plans and them revealing them to your side. Just gonna put it blunt, it F*cks with your mind, this game has a lot of tricks up its sleeves.... From surprising plot twists to last minute turn arounds, the games in this could go ANYWHERE.  The player customizer is spectacular, the options are just incredible and with new update every holiday and so often, you can never have enough skins or pets. It may be hard working for it, but you can't help but grin when you walk into that circle with a doge or a huge dark horse descending down on your fellow townies.  So now, why you should buy the game over playing in browser; No ads, Free money, Faster loading speed, another way of connecting with the amazing, mind boggling people you meet on the games and basically, overall enjoyment  My rating for this game is a mighty 9/10, this is because of the sheer enjoyment of the game, i have met several friends on this game and have played with cool youtubers like SquirrelsMK, because of the awesome party feauture, its certain that she can play with her subscribers and they can enjoy playing aswell, rather than just joining at the same time, hoping for the best. But, sadly, i can not give a perfect 10 for some games being ruined as of cheaters in the games, and i know its nearly impossible to prevent at the start of the game, but me and squirrels alike have had mafia, sk or just any games ruined by other mafia members or cheaters. That sums up my review, this game is perfect solo or with friends in a party.

Town of Salem is a fun and easy to play game with friends. Although at first it may seem very complicated, it is easily grasped by players. In-game purchases do not affect gameplay, as most of what is offered are cosmetic items. Scrolls give the possibility of getting a role that is favored, however it is not guaranteed, and the strategy that the game requires is not affected, although it seems that many people are more willing to lynch a person who has an evil skin. Overall, this game is addicting, competetive, stategic, and fun. It is one of my favorites to play when I am bored, and it occupies most of my brain space in the moment. 10/10. Before purchasing this game, be aware that it is available for free on their website. However, purchasing through steam allows greater in-game benefits and faster earned MP for spending. I'm still not sure if buying it on steam was actually worth it, but for the time i've put into this game, I am sure it won't be a waste.

I'm new to this kind of games. I found this game through a discovery queue on 30th of dec. Reviews complained about a rather unappealing moves by the devs trying to get money for cosmetics. Reviews also pointed out that there's a free version on their web site and that's where I went. I was pretty confused while trying to figure out what's what's and who's the real McCoy for the most part of the day. Probably still have a LOT more to learn. I kept going for, “one more game” till the morning of 31th.  -The devs moves with cosmetics&money DO look ugly. Check the update news though, they're not THAT “evil”. -The game IS 100% playable (and enjoyable, unless you're a skin junkie of some kind) for free. Only cosmetics are walled behind RM (not all of them btw). -Scrolls are the only item type that affects the actual gameplay. They affect your  chances  of getting the associated roles and don't work in Ranked mode. -Scrolls are NOT walled behind RM. -It's an enjoyable game, at least from my newbie perspective.  I get why some old players are irritated, yet it's a freely enjoyable game. I got more that it's steam cost worth of fun already and I got it for free. In my opinion that deserves a positive review/recommendation.  P.S. If my review has convinced you to try the game, feel free to put me (Reianor) as a referrer when registering. Try it for free first. If you like it enough to spend money then I'll have gotten a referrer bonus and you … well you'll have gotten to play a game that you liked enough to spend money on. Win/win, right?  P.P.S. I'd get into details about the game itself, but if that is your main concern than you're better off looking for info in some other reviews. There are people out there who have played this game and similar games for waaaay longer than I did, their input should be more valuable. Just mind the dates, and like I said, check the news to see if their info is still up to date. All I can say is that the gameplay feedback I've looked through was positive. Well, that and, for what it's worth, that my own inexperienced experience was positive.

Town of Salem is an intricate game regarding how well you can deceive, manipulate and trick other players. It is full with a profusion of stratergies and roles that a player can receive.  The player then has to act out the goal of these roles. Every game is full of different people and different roles accompanied by different stratergies so the game always feels fresh. You can play the browser version for free on the official BlankMediaGames website or you can purchase the steam version to support the creators and will be rewarded with 1300 coins for doing so.  There are different cosmetic items in the game so there's no pay to win aspect. You can easily get these items with the in-game currency and don't have to spend anything to get them. If you wish to speed up the process you can buy these coins but it's not necessary.  The game has multiple modes. Classic is basically the starter mode you should use. There are custom games you can create with custom role lists to have so chaotic fun. Also there are chaos gamemdoes which are basically a cluster♥♥♥♥ and really fun to Play.  Once you are sick of Classic and are eager for more you can try out the Ranked Practise mode. In this, everything is harder and has more roles. Once you get the hang of Ranked Practise you can try out Ranked. This is for more serious and competitive players and still is a lot of fun.  Overall town of salem is an intricate game and worth getting on steam or playing on the official BlankMediaGames website. Honestly one of my favourite games at this common time and there's no lag involved. Meaning you're not going to get ♥♥♥♥ed over because people in your house are downloading.

SERIOUS REVIEW  When i first saw this game on saw i thought 'eh, why not?', so i bought it. I can say that this game is worth every penny  You may be asking 'You can play this game for free! Why should i pay for it when i can play for free?' Well, first of all the servers are 10x faster than the brower version  Every single game you play is different, especially when you get roles like Serial Killer or a Mafia Member On the other hand you can play boring and 1 time use roles like Medium or Retributionist (Ret. can bring one person back to life (But most of the time they get killed right after again))  Once you play 50 games, you can play ranked which i havent gotten to try out yet but im getting there  To sum all of it up ill do Pros and Cons  Pros:  - Variety  - 3 Different game modes  - 31 roles  - you can play with friends (create a lobby)  - Worth the 4.99 (Would recommend buying on sale ;))  - Coins can buy cosmetics, houses, pets, death animations, and player skins/costumes (You can buy coins or earn them buy playing games over time)  - You sometime get deals that are very cheap Examples: Vampire Deal: Vampire Skin, Vampire house, 1300 coins, etc. FOR ONLY 0.99! NOTE: The buyable things in TOS is basically hats from TF2 (Money Grabbers ;) )  - STEAM ACHIEVEMENTS :))))))))))))) (GO GET SOME AND SHOWOFF HOW GOOD YOU ARE)  Cons:  - 3 gamemodes, im sure overtime they will add more gamemodes but for now what you get is what you got.  - GAMETHROWERS, although these are rare sometimes you will join a game with a guy who will tell who the entire mafia is and ruin the game for everyone.  - 4.99 coin packs for only 1500 coins, as i said before Coins are equal to TF2 Hats, they suck you in and steal your money. (If you lowered the price or gave more coins for 4.99 i would consider buying coins.   In conclusion, Town of Salem: Steam Version is an amazing game and you should support the developers!  9/10  PS: WHATEVER PEOPLE SAY THERE ARE NO POP-UP ADS!

Town of Salem is massively enjoyable, especially when you consider how it manages to create mystery, suspense and strategic situations with so little. Each role (mostly) has an interesting thing to do, some roles are dull and are based entirely on luck and nothing else, but overall, you can develop your own strategy for each character and use it to the advantage (or disadvantage) of the group. Right, it is a really good game. Really engaged and good fun to play with...however...  What ruins the game is the sheer level of cheating and bad form displayed by a lot of players. I've had the good fortune to play with some excellent players and have great games. But on the majority of occasions, I end up stuck with some really rude, bigotted, spamming and sometimes peadophillic people. I report them of course, but the next game or so, there they are again, and aiming to ruin the game for me because I called them on it.   In some games as well, people actually cheat by telling people IRL who did what. For example, N1 as SK I killed the escort. Escort did not leave a will, ya know, the main way of communicating after you die (less the medium) and I got lynched because another person in the game was sat in the same room as the escort, and the escort told him. After trying to defend myself, as you would if you want to try to win, I was labelled a '♥♥♥' and told to 'go cry yu f***, b***** die in a fire' and so on...as if I chose to be the SK and then was totally in the wrong for trying to escape a lynching!   This is the only element of the game I find completely offputting, that this is going on, and it ruins games and throws it into complete bias. Everybody should have a fair shot at winning, and not get screwed over so easily by people who use their own mechanics to swing games. Adding in the fact that you get personally attacked by these people for actually trying to play the game. I know that monitoring a chat service is difficult and rely's on the players reporting, but the report function is not sufficient, especially when you can't give a reason for the report. And I am aware that there is no real way that the developers can stop this from happening, same as WoW can't really do much against gold farmers.  I would recommend it, but I do hope the developers are aware that this type of player ruins it for everybody else, and is, as such, the only, albeit quite seriously so, offputting part of the game.

Town of Salem. It's fun in a 'Guess Who' sort of way.   Pretty much two teams of people (and some unaffiliated people) in a town trying to collect information or convince the others of this or that.  No one knows what anyone else is at first. Everyone chooses a name, the game begins, and you're given a random role which no one knows but you.  There's a buncha roles. With each having their own ability and goal. Some need to lynch or kill the enemy team. Some just need to survive to the end of the game regardless of which team wins. Some even win by getting lynched.   Roles basically boil down to either collecting information, attacking other players, defending other players, blocking other players from performing their actions, or misleading other players. All of which are done in various ways.  This game has the effect much like Civilization. You keep deciding to play just one more game (or 'turn' in Civ's case) but before you know it you've played 10 more games. Especially if you play with friends and laugh over the dumb names people use and the silly last-wills and death-notes they make.

In current times I often find myself unable to stick to games. I tend to usually put maybe 10 hours into a game and lose interest, but this game has officially made itself an exception. This game is truly something i never expected to get in a video game. Very reminiscent of a type of game my friends and i might play as a board game of some sort while sitting at a table, this game makes itself special. There are very few games that are able to constantly have you put in a unique situation every single time you play. Town of Salem, of course, manages to pull this off because the entire premise of the game is that the entire game is molded by the players in each game.   Now sometimes you may encounter the occasional annoying or bad player online, but it's made up for because for the majority of the time, they are unable to COMPLETELY ruin a session. They may cause some loss of immersion into the game, but the other 13 players will tend to for the most part remain immersed in the game along with you.   Having a large list of roles, this game has portions of role play i haven't yet gotten to experience even after more than 100 matches, and i expect nothing but more fun in the future for other sessions i play. This game is incredibly amazing, and even if you do not feel like spending money on the game, it is free to play online on your browser. Give it a shot, invite all your friends (you get an awesome grim reaper skin if you refer 5 friends), and you won't regret it.

Some of the HUD is cluttered and confusing, but overall manageable. I still would not recommend this game to anyone but masochists and people who get off on trolling others.

First of all, yes, this is a free to play game. You can play the free version on their website, and i would certainly recommend you to try it before you buy it on Steam.  So why would you buy this? The reason i recommend this version is the better performance when compared to the browser version. The Steam version also comes with $5 worth of Town Points to purchase skins and death animations ingame. You could also consider this purchase a small donation to support the developers, because i think the game is a well made replication of the boardgame that is definitely worth playing and keeps you busy for days. This is why i nominated this game for the 'Just 5 more minutes!'- Steamaward 2016.  Lastly i want to say that so far, the developers have shown really good support for their game with frequent updates that introduced new balancing, community requested features and new skins every now and then. I really appreciate the good support because sadly this is not the norm these days.

I would love to try playing a game or two with you guys as well.  Update: I forgot to mention something, the game tends to be heavy on marketing so.. any gold income you would try to gain legitimately is low, 5 gold if, IF you win. So gl trying to get passed the newly found greed... I still play but the marketing is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me way the ♥♥♥♥ off now.

*Written on day of release*  Most of the review is written with the browser game in mind.  Town of Salem is a damn smart concept for a game that is simply Mafia vs. Town. The game plays out well, with all the roles working well together to make a fairly challenging lobby of truth and deception, with a few wildcards such as the Serial Killer (Who kills for fun), and the Witch (Who controls people and messes up their plans)  Positives;  -A good time killer if ever you're bored, -It's easy to understand, but difficult to master, -Not CPU intensive, so most machines should be able to run the game, -Customisable Negatives; -'Fullscreen' button doesn't work. -There is no 'Leave game' button. -Premades can ruin the game pretty easily  Edit: Whatever chat bug i was suffering from has resolved itself, and i reformatted the review and had a change of heart.

tl;dr review: Town of Salem is a free to play web browser game. Instead of paying $5 for the Steam version, you can register on the game's site and play there for free.  Game is actually a quick and fun social game. Addicting when its played right. Even after you die, its still entertaining to watch the remainder of the game as people play really well or screw up really hard because they're so dumb.  Unfortuantely this is a big fat 'no' for 3 main reasons.   as stated in the tl;dr, the game is free to play. I don't know why the Steam version isn't FTP, but the $5 you spend on the game gives you $5 worth of in game currency to buy garbage.  2nd no is nature of game being a social game. Every now and then you'll run into a group of x-chaners or some other misanthropes who sit there and type obsenities or they play as a group to cheat and throw games because LEL XD so funnay!  3rd no is based on principal.   To combat foul mouthed children and idiots, the developers of Town of Salem put in a word filter. It replaces all the vulgarity with inoffensive terms. You can type ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥, etc, all you want no problem... But DON'T YOU DARE type any SJW or feminazi trigger words! You'll get banned from the game for sexual harassment you bigoted homophobe!  Seriosuly, words that aren't swears or offensvie even. Stuff like r-ape and molester are blocked and issue you a warning that can lead to game suspension. Homo, which isn't even an anti-gay slur, is also blocked.   The SJW/Feminist thought policing is weird given the subject of the game. There is a vocal group of idiots who swear lynching is racist. And that's what you do as a group in Town of Salem.

Let's face it; this game is available for free. There is no real benefit in buying the steam version, what you get are faster loading times and the spend money as in game currency (yes it has an in game cosmetic shop). I recommend you to try the browser version first; you can use your account if you think about buying it later. Now about the game.   The game is a social game, similar to some board games like Werewolf, Mafia or Secret Hitler.  The gameplay will focus mainly around lying/deceiving and strategically eliminating targets. What I like most in this game is the fact that there are no 'empty' roles, ofc. you have some roles which are more Important/powerful than others, but you always have an ability to influence the game outside from talking.  The game offers some different game modes with a huge variety of roles which really shakes up the gameplay if your standard mode gets dull.  Positive:      entertaining gameplay    nice artstyle    mostly balanced roles (often a problem in these kind of games)    nice soundtrack   Negative:     horrible menus (you can see the flash past of this game)   no option to punish cheaters/leavers (cheating in talking with people outside of the game or playing with multiple accounts)   Final Words: Try it, decide later. This game has a great concept, if they released a recoded version with a proper Ui and Hd-textures as well as an anti-cheat system I'd say it’s even worth 10-15€, for now the solid gameplay (and cheap price) allows me to look over these problems. A little, very unpolished, gem in my library

This game is probably one of the best part games out there. It's very fun in the sense of murder mystery and pretty much every role is essential in the game towards helping catch the bad guys or if you're the bad guy, getting rid of the good guys. No matter which side you play on it's a lot of fun. In terms of pros I would say ;   + good variety of roles each with their own abilities and attributes +custom gamemodes where you can add multiple roles/ ban roles for added chaos  + stuff such as the will system, talking to the dead, questioning as jailor, etc. make it somewhat complex and more interesting +fairly easy to pick up +there is a cash shop HOWEVER you can earn free coins through acheivements and first wins of the day. These coins can be used to unlock cosmetics and scrolls which give you a higher chance to land on whatever role the scroll is for  However despite how fun this game is, it still has some flaws;   -for a mainly text based game with fairly simple animations it still sometimes lags which can be annoying considering the game revolves around typing so if you're about to be lynched and you need to type up something fast in your defense and a lag spike hits it's annoying as heck -the community for this game sometimes makes me question humanity. Not only will you get lynched for the stupidest things but also some of these people can't put two and two together. Also a lot of bad trolls such as mafia who will reveal other mafia members, vig purposefully shooting people like mayor, etc.   All in all it's a pretty good game. Keep in mind though that the steam version only unlocks acheivements and some points for the cash shop but you can play this game for free on their official website. I'll give this game an 8/10, I would personally recommend playing with friends if you can as thats when it is the most fun

I palyed this game for a long time in browser and was one of the backers for the kickstarter, so my real playtime is probably 50 hours more, and I plan on putting plenty of hours into this marvelous game. The object of the game is to win with your faction, Town, Mafia, or Neutral (dependent.) There are several game modes that affect the amount and roles of members in each faction, in custom mode the host chooses the roles and this can lead to some less than fun matches, BUT you always have the option to leave the lobby. Each faction has several members (Depending on the faction or allignment.) Your goals are displayed in the upper right hand corner of the game and it is very easy to learn the basics, yet the more subtle launguage and clever moves people use may take longer to learn.   The abilities differ from randomly selected role to role, you cna be a Serial Killer bent on murdering each and every member of the town, a crime boss leading a group of mafia members to become the last people standing, a kindly doctor whose goal it is to make sure your target survives the night, or even a madman whose soul goal is to be hung through the voting system in game, allowing him to 'haunt' someone who voted him guilty.   The game has two sections, the day section where members talk to each other through an implemented text chat function (No voice chat, sorry!) and decie if someone needs to be hung by the town and if so the members vote on who is guilty or innocent once someeone is sent on trial. The night phase does not allow comunication (excpet through special roles and mafia members) and allows roles to use there special abilites, such as choosing someone to murder or protect (Whilst avoiding detection)  Each game is an entire different experience, and the game as a whole is very rewarding and msot certainly worth its miniscule $4.99 pricetag. I LOVE THIS GAME!  I used to play an Arcade game in Starcraft 2 called MAFIA. This is exactly the same game, but it's even better because it's constantly being managed, so there will be new features and PROGRESS.  Town of Salem is a relaxing indie game. It's inexpensive (free for non-steam Users), it's fun, and it requires a lot of thinking! It's really, really fun breaking down who is who and what to do next. People CAN be irritating sometimes, but, come on, that's a given in any online game, am i right? As for ranked, it is a pretty pleasant community/environment from my own perspective. There are rarely any leavers before death and a lot of ranked players understand the game, which makes it easier to get carried and to learn more!   I feel like this game should be more popular, and I will do my best to support this game!

This game is suppose to be a detective type of game.  You along with all the other townsfolk are suppose to figure out who are the killers in the town and kill them. But, this game is too restrictive and doesn't allow that much depth for the player to investigate. You are restricted in all roles given to you and you are not allowed much choices to choose from within said roles. You will always have to rely on the chat in game and hope someone is gonna 'gamethrow' or hope someone is telling the truth about something they seen. But there is no way to know if they are, so this results in players distrusting everyone and pretty much ready to kill everyone without good rhyme or reason besides 'evidence' which is not trustworthy at all.  The customization in the game is decent but barely noticable. You are given a restrictive set of choices to choose from. The ui is big and clunky and not having enough choices to pick from.   Overall, it has a nice concept but it's poorly excuted here.

A fun Mafia-esque game. While it doesn't quite have the social aspect of playing in person, the software version enables a number of roles that wouldn't be feasible in in person games (like the Jailor, the Spy, etc).  Everyone has their own role to play (with some people working towards the same objective), and most have some related power to use, so you're not just a generic villiager. There are still some roles are more fun/powerful/better than others (eg, Jester, Executioner and Survivor are probably among the least fun) .  Overall, a good game if you like Mafia-style games. I do wish they would improve the lobbies, though. There are a few lobbies with a set configuration and one thats user-defined, but no way of grouping people togethr who want the same user configured game , or grouping people together by how well they play. Hopefully this gets improved in the future.

Town of Salem is a multiplayer strategy role-playing game with a simple design yet very engaging gameplay. There are a lot of reasons to love this game, and there is no reason you shouldn't play it as there is a free browser version available. The only reason I use the Steam version is for better accessibility, and the only benefit is that you get five dollars worth of town points.  Pros -Huge variety of roles to explore -Many different game modes to play -A ranked mode for competitive and experience players (like me) -Can play with up to 14 other players -Very easy-to-use and simple interface -Ability to chat about your info (or lie about it) -Multiple phases of gameplay -Ability to have friends -Great background music -Very well balanced  Cons -Can be easy to get screwed by events out of your control -Somewhat steep learning curve -Sometimes your arguments won't work despite them being true   Overall, this game does have minor issues, but they are GREATLY outweighed by the good parts. This game gets a 10/10 from me and I would definitely recommend this game to you. Just don't spend your money on the Steam version and play it for free on your browser. (I only did it for better access.)

Functional, but doesn't look good. - Skype call groups can ruin some game - Afk players or quitters can really screw you over  As far as actual gameplay goes I give it a 10/10. I love it. Manipulate, Lie, Barter, all to survive in the town of Salem!  People talk about trolls/♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but honestly this game is about survival. If you are a serial killer, then of course you are going to lie and manipulate people so you don't get hanged!  If you are mafia, of course you are going to frame and set up people so they don't know it is you doing the evil deeds at night.  If you are a werewolf, of course you are going to try to bend the truth so people don't hang you for it.  If you are the townsmen, of course you are going to whisper with others and try to figure out 'who is on your side' so you can band together to eliminate the 'bad guys.'  I am enjoying the game after 4 hours of play and maybe 20 different games.  The games can be quick, maybe take 10 mins, sometimes 15. Your role is generally random, and if you die, you don't have to stick around until the end of the game.  A unique game type I have not experienced before. Intrigue, bartering, mystery, manipulation; it is fun. I am a nice person but it is interesting trying to spin things within the game to get someone else Hanged when you are in fact the serial killer.

Alrighty, Let's see Town of Salem, what can I say about you? Let me ignore the ~80 minutes I spent, unable to create an account. It could've been a lot worse after all. And it was worth it! First Impressions: At first I thought 'Oh no, I'm not prepared, what do I do when I get a role that's hard to have?', but after a few moments of utter anxiety I decided to just jump in: I joined a Classic, Classic Game, and the game gave me the role of the Sheriff. I kept quiet mostly, I didn't see anyone suspicious. Also I noticed you could leave a message on death, thus I simply filled in everything I found, everyone who was innocent. And I didn't die. At the end of the game, only 3 of us were left. And the Serial Killer was trying to blame me. I revealed my role and luckily the other townie believed me. We won because the only other townie trusted me.  The Second Game threw me right into the Serial Killer role. I managed to kill 5 people without even popping up in the suggestions then someone just declared to 'Randomly lynch' me. I was still happy, I mean, I learned from that.  The Third Game I was a vigilante. I didn't do anything and we won in the end by luck mostly.  The fourth game I was an executioner. They killed my target in the night though, so I ended up as a jester. Then I was killed in the night aswell. The fifth game directly spawned me as a jester and I was killed in the night but it was fun.  The sixth game then spawned me as a Veteran... and I wasted my 3 alerts cause half the nights, nobody would get killed.  The seventh and my last game so far, then introduced me to the role of the jailor. I didn't last very long, got killed in night two, missed the icon to take someone with me in night one. I still enjoyed it very much.  The people I met were surprisingly mature and also had a decent spelling, something you can barely see in some communities and not once did I feel unskilled or scared of failure. Failure is fun, it's amazing to see how it all plays out.  And I don't really have any complaints either. Every role is explained by some boxes on screen, there was no time where I thought 'Oh gosh, what am I doing?' The nights nobody attacked anyone made the game longer, sure, but those few minutes? Oh Please! I'm very patient.  If you're a fan of tabletop games that are like this game, e.g. One Night - Ultimate Werewolf, I can recommend this very much. It may seem silly but that sort of Tabletop game is something you need at the very least 6 people to play and have it be fun. Here? you can avoid the player count entirely because it's online!  Now that I think about it, I do have one complaint. I can't seem to stop playing. Heh~!  Yeah, this game is a fun title and I can recommend it to you. If you need numbers, here are some: 13 92 46 85.  And here are some of the other aspects I may have missed:  Sound: Nice Menu OST, but a tad loud, crank it down to 1% Volume and it'll be alright.  Graphics: You can see those in the videos and screenshots provided, Character models don't influence gameplay,  feel free to buy some for the looks if you want, but ultimately it doesn't change anything.   Gameplay: If you like the idea behind it, you'll love this game. That's all.  Community: Seems decent, except for a few lonely trolls who can usually be seen cursing and disconnecting, nothing worth mentioning. If someone goes on about it being their first time and that they don't get anything in the ingame chat? Most likely Jesters wanting to be executed, no trolls or griefers. Yeah, the community isn't abusive but half the time they are incredibly thick, could be frustrating if you play to win. I play for fun and guess what: That it is!  Overall (aka, the bit you skip to if this is TL, DR): I love it. I recommend it. That's it.  Edit:  After 20 Hours of playtime it's STILL fun! Take that as you wish.

So I discovered this game about a year ago and for about...8 or 9 months, I played it daily. I was actually addicted.  I have a far healthier relationship with this game now, and I believe I am better qualified to talk about it and its flaws.  This is without question my second most played game on Steam beating out other games like Skyrim, Mass Effect, Garry's Mod, Civ 5, Borderlands 2, Crusader Kings 2... the only thing I have played more is Team Fortress 2.  Town of Salem is a 15-player version of Mafia/Werewolf. It pits multiple teams and factions against each other to determine the victor, and unlike some of the more common versions of Mafia that you might play in real life with friends, EVERYONE has a specific power to get information, remove information or more generally influence the game. There is no one who is 'just a Townie' and that is perhaps my favorite part on this take of the game.  The second big twist is that there can be multiple bad guys who are competing against each other. It's not always just 'large group of innocents who don't know who everyone is Vs. small group of bad guys who know who everyone is.'  All of the different roles make any given game different from any other, but I've found that most of the fun in the game depends on the other players. A single jerk can utterly ruin a game as they deliberately draw attention away from gameplay and force the townies to waste time policing them instead of playing the game - this is made complicated by the fact that there are roles like the Jester and Executioner that take advantage of such behavior! Or a faction like Town, Mafia or Vampires can be utterly cripples beyond any hope of winning if a lot of players leave the game at once. There are penalities to discourage such behavior but that doesn't always make a difference.  All of this being said, you may wonder why such a variable game that is dependant on other people not being horrible wastes-of-space is getting a recommendation from me.  Well, what other game can you win as a Serial Killer named 'Cannot Lie' when you tell everyone from the get-go exactly what you're going to do, when you're going to do it...and they think you're just a really good Jester?  Only in Salem.

This game is absolutely amazing! I love it and it makes me feel a little bit better every single time I play it. As a person who suffers from depression, this game has made an amazing impact on my life and so has it's wonderful community. However I obviously have to be honest when reviewing this game so here is the actual review.  Game mechanics are great, and work for the game. It clearly doesn't try to be something that it simply isn't. Graphics are pretty good and it even runs on my crappy laptop. It is fairly balanced is quite a bit of fun if you play on custom mode and associate yourself with people.  Now here comes the issues I have with it. I admit this game is pretty good considering how few of people are working on it, with this said I feel a few adjustments could be made. The graphics are great, however I feel there could be obvious improvement made to them (less like Minecraft preferably). The game is fairly balanced but the Vigilante is a bit underwhelming and at the very least should be able to defy night immunity. Next off is a small issue with the community. Cursing and spam is rather overwhelming in the game, especially for a younger audience. I of course am certainly not in that audience, but I feel there should be a way to at least limit it. The idea I had for it was to add a report bar in the lobby (though I know it will be misused for people reporting the host for... well, hosting).  Above all, this game is pretty amazing. It is worth BUYING the game rather than using the game on a browser due to the fact you get great coin benefits (In game currency)! You also support the people who make this game possible. Thanks for reading this review! Have fun with this game :) I wish you luck!

Do you enjoy governing organized crime? Do you draw pleasure from messing with people's minds? Most importantly, do you find yourself proficient at lying through your teeth and getting away with murder? If you answered yes to those questions, then this game is for you. Town of Salem is a psychologist's wet dream. More specifically, it is the card game 'mafia' but online! With 15 people in a lobby divided between Town, Mafia, and Misc. evil roles all clamoring for different winning conditions, things get hectic. In that hectic clamor, human nature and power plays shine through in glorious fashion.  The game sports 30 distinct roles separated into different classes and alignments, most are as fun as the next. Granted, the game needs some balancing done on particular roles (Neutral killing and disguiser, specifically), but the game is PHENOMENAL at its very core. It is worth every penny. I have personally clocked about 460 hours and I'm still going strong. The devs are also looking to expand and cultivate the game, which will only make it even better.   10/10  -W&H

I really enjoy this game. This is that 'secret role' game a lot like the party game Werewolf, I assume. I've never played that game and this allows me to explore that. It's a fun game full of roles that take some getting used to game mechanics and the specific roles to fully understand.   A good game with good players is extremely enjoyable. Of course you run into a lot of people who throw matches, troll or just don't care who make some games less desirable.   The game is not very well explained. You're thrown into a game with real people with just a brief description of your role and have to figure everything else out. Ultimately it's not a big deal but I can see that being a big turn off to a lot of people.   The big draw for me is the ability to play a big party game with people and enjoy social interactions with them. Not having a whole lot of friends, this game fills that void. Also, you will end up with some real laugh out loud moments from people's reactions and how they deal with things. You'll also be left in disbelief as you totally explain to the other people how you know someone is a serial killer or in the mafia with all the evidence you have and then somehow you still end up getting lynched. Facepalm! All in good fun though.

It's worth paying money for it because you get $5 worth of the in game currency, which is purely cosmetic, in addition to faster loading times, although even in the browser version the loading times aren't bad at all. You also get to support the developers of this fantastic game. So even though this game is available for free, I really suggest supporting the developers and buying it on Steam, but maybe try it out for free if you're not sure.  Now for the actual review. I bought this game on a whim during the summer sale because it was cheap and had a pretty good approval rating. I didn't really expect to play it that much, but now it has more hours logged than any of the other games I bought during that sale. This game is super addicting, and I play a game of it almost every day. The rounds are fairly short, and usually last 15-30 minutes. If you just want a mindless game without a lot of thinking in it, or a game where you don't have to communicate with other people, then this game isn't for you. This game requires that you work with other people and strategize, deceive, and often try and mess with their heads. This does come with the downside of working with other people though, where there will be the occasional troll, and sometimes people can be fairly annoying, and offensive at times. There is a chat filter to block out some of the stuff people might find offensive, however I have noticed there are some words it doesn't block out that it probably should.  Town of Salem is pretty easy to pick up, although there is a bit of a learning curve. I was really confused my first few games, but I picked it up pretty quickly after that. While it can be pretty easy to play this after a few games, it takes quite a while to learn enough to be really good at it. You have to not only know about your own role, but you have to know about the other roles in the game as well. Knowing whether a role is town protective or town support can help weed out who's lying and who's telling the truth. I really recommend taking a look at the role list on  blankmediagames.com  to get a bit more familiar with some of the roles. There's also a bit of a learning curve in learning how to strategise and manipulate properly. My second round in this game, I was the jester, which is a role where you want to be lynched my your fellow townspeople. I claimed I was the serial killer on the first day, and it became really obvious that I was the jester. You have to think a lot about ways to manipulate the other people into doing what you want.  This game is definitley not one that was created by the developers and then left to die. This game was updated just recently, with a new role, the forger, and a bunch of new cosmetic stuff in the shop, as well as some bug fixes and a bit of a UI change. The developers also have more stuff they are planning for Town of Salem, so dont' worry about never getting anything new with this game, because the developers have shown they actually care about this game.  I could go into so much more detail with this game, it has so much depth and I've never played two games that went the same. I could talk about the pros and cons of each role and how they work, but this review is already too long, so I'll let you play the game yourself and figure it out, which really is one of the best parts of this game. I cannot recommend this game enough, everyone should at least give it a chance, especially because you can play it for free.  Pros: +Addicting +Lots of depth +You can try it for free +Easy to play, difficult to master +No two games are the same +Short rounds +Lots of strategy and thinking +Dozens if not hundreds of hours of gameplay  Cons: -People can be annoying -Confusing at first  The pros definitley outweigh the cons for Town of Salem, and I really cannot recommend this game enough. It's a brilliant and unique game that anyone can play and enjoy.  Edit: I previously had the reporting system listed as a con, however since then the reporting system has been significantly improved, allowing you to select an actual reason for reporting them and list comments. In addition, the chat filter, while still not perfect, has become considerably more humerous, switching out offensive words with words like flummery and tarnation. It automatically replaces 'You Suck' or 'X Sucks' with 'You are a great player' or 'X is a great player,' which is always funny.

Lets start with the game itself. The backround is this: a group of townsmen and women group in the center of thier village. Little do they know is that among them, there is mafia, serial killers, and more. As the game progresses, more and more of the townspeople gets picked off, untill Mafia, or the serial killer, is the last men/man standing. The paticulars are these: Every person has a role. These roles include Sheriff, Jailor, Serial Killer, Godfather, and many, many more. Each of these roles has a special ability or trait: for example, the serial killer has the abilty to kill one person each night, unless they are protected by another role, such as escort. This simple mechanic of roles creates a game of lying, strategy, and tough decisions. The way you win is to basically either protect the town by killing the 'bad' teams and roles, or by picking off all of the 'good' roles. Another extremly important concept is the gallows. Every in game day, you can put a single towns member on trial. If they prove guilty, you can vote to execute them. In conclusion, this game has:     RPG aspects    Multiplayer    Strategy    Lying    Actually important roles   Even though this review has a lot, it doesn't even come close to the true fun, excitement, and glory that come from this game.

This game has literally no gameplay. That's not actually a bad thing though. Town of Salem is a game of words and persuasion. You try to sniff out the evil town members and lynch them. For example, let's say that you are the Serial Killer, you are an evil town member and you are trying to kill everyone in the town without them knowing who did it. You will wait for night time and choose a target to eliminate. The next morning you see their dead body spread out on the ground, and people suspect you. You could go multiple ways with this. You could say 'I did not murder them, I am an Investigator, and (insert name here) visited them last night, it must be them!' Essentially it is a game of manipulation, trust, and deception. I highly recommend this game. Just choose your words right.

This game is a fairly simple, yet oddly addictive version of 'mafia'. It is fun to chat with others while trying to figure out who in the crap just killed that guy, or why the jailor killed the doctor. You meet people of all personalities; some who take the game very seriously, and some who are just there to goof around. You can be a doctor, and heal everyone; a detective, and watch 'cookie901' every night, or be a serial killer and stab everyone with the letter 'k' in their name. The list of roles goes on and on. It is fun and lively, and you never know who you can trust... *shifty eyes* Anyways, I recommend it to anyone that has spare time, and wants to spend it solving mysteries, or being the mystery-maker....  Overall, a pretty good game, and a great way to spend that extra 10 minutes before you have to sprint to the car and drive off in a caffine-fueled haze to your boring job at the brewery where you stand at the production line and slap the tops onto bottles of beer that you wish you could afford.  10 outta 10, would play again!

So I discovered this game about a year ago and for about...8 or 9 months, I played it daily. I was actually addicted.  I have a far healthier relationship with this game now, and I believe I am better qualified to talk about it and its flaws.  This is without question my second most played game on Steam beating out other games like Skyrim, Mass Effect, Garry's Mod, Civ 5, Borderlands 2, Crusader Kings 2... the only thing I have played more is Team Fortress 2.  Town of Salem is a 15-player version of Mafia/Werewolf. It pits multiple teams and factions against each other to determine the victor, and unlike some of the more common versions of Mafia that you might play in real life with friends, EVERYONE has a specific power to get information, remove information or more generally influence the game. There is no one who is 'just a Townie' and that is perhaps my favorite part on this take of the game.  The second big twist is that there can be multiple bad guys who are competing against each other. It's not always just 'large group of innocents who don't know who everyone is Vs. small group of bad guys who know who everyone is.'  All of the different roles make any given game different from any other, but I've found that most of the fun in the game depends on the other players. A single jerk can utterly ruin a game as they deliberately draw attention away from gameplay and force the townies to waste time policing them instead of playing the game - this is made complicated by the fact that there are roles like the Jester and Executioner that take advantage of such behavior! Or a faction like Town, Mafia or Vampires can be utterly cripples beyond any hope of winning if a lot of players leave the game at once. There are penalities to discourage such behavior but that doesn't always make a difference.  All of this being said, you may wonder why such a variable game that is dependant on other people not being horrible wastes-of-space is getting a recommendation from me.  Well, what other game can you win as a Serial Killer named 'Cannot Lie' when you tell everyone from the get-go exactly what you're going to do, when you're going to do it...and they think you're just a really good Jester?  Only in Salem.

The gameplay is quite balanced in terms of roles, as most of them impact the game a lot if you know what you're doing. I really disagree with the idea of scrolls though, which can be bought for ingame money (which can be bought with actual money..) to increase your chances of being that role drastically. This makes it harder to be an interesting class, but i still get mafia or serial killer quite often!  Town of Salem is a free game on the internet, which is where most people start off (and most just stay there), so i definitely suggest to give it a try

You've called Mr box to the stand, he trembles and proclaims himself to be the retributionist. He pleds to prove his innocence but the jailor would have none of it. Finally the last evil doer is to be brought to justice. The jailor makes the call, to be hung without mercy. As the rope snaps tight you look into his swinging body with immense satisfaction. Nothing can beat the feeling of knowing you have won!  Only he was the retributionist, he could have brought back an investigator who would have discovered the true identity of the arsonist. That night the arsonist burns the rest of the town to the ground... Guess you can't win them all?  Truely Town of Salem is one of a kind, taking the essence of mass hysteria and turning it into a fun replayable game which has you saying 'just one more round'. It combines the process of emilination you would expect from a game like cluedo and human intrigue, creating this beautiful mind game.  A good casual game to just pick up when you have a free 15 minutes or so, highly recommend if you are into psychological/investigative games.

Amongst all the discontentedness with the recent update, many reviewers are leaving out information on the actual gameplay. First off, the changes to currency system only really pay-gates the newest cosmetic items whilst allowing the older cosmetics to be purchable with ingame-earned currency as well as the premium currency. It doesn't affect gameplay much, except that you won't have that flashy skin that might otherwise convince people to kill you (which may or may not be a bad thing depending upon your role.)  Gameplay-wise, Town of Salem requires a sharp mind and quick thinking to master, but anyone can hop on and enjoy the feeling of choosing to make an attempt on another player's life -- or make an attempt to protect them from harm. Which role is given to you is randomly picked via a wheel-of-fortune-esque animation displaying the possibilities, and the percentage of recieving it.  I'm not especially good at describing it, but it's a fun game, but the community certainly can be immature, so I wouldn't call it a PG game due to how online interaction works. PG-13+, perhaps. Regardless, give it a shot, lose a few games, kill a few people, and have a laugh at the insanity you may experience.

I love the game, i really do. its an amazing game, near perfect balancing. i could come up with a few nit picky reasons but i wont. my only complaint with the game is the recent currency update Before hand, town points got you stuff in the shop, such as cosmetics and scrolls which gave you a better chance of getting a certain role in an non ranked game. nothing wrong with that, these were earned through playing, winning, etc. as well as purchasable through the store. However, this recent update introduced a new currency that is a silver coin. Now town points can only be obtained through buying with real money. Nearly all if not all of the cosmetics can only be obtained with town points. This means now they are locked behind buying with real money only. Now i personally do not have an issue with that, if you need money to upkeep your game i get that. Making cosmetic items, some of them only obtained by real money is fine. You can also hide your appearance from other players as some will lynch or kill you based on your look and name. So this is not a major issue. You may be wondering why then am i downvoting if i dont have an issue with it? My reason is they made PRE EXISTING items behind the paywall, which i think is stupid. is it bad? no. But its stupid and not necessary. Had they kept stuff as it, and made some or all new items being released with that paywall i would be less frustrated. Not just that, but this type of business practive, having cool free items then saying 'nah we gonna charge you for it' Maybe they need the money, i dont know. But i dont like how they did it, and i think without real warning it just happened. That bothers me, they is not a business practice i wish to support.  However, the game is still really fun, and for 5 bucks its amazing. But i refuse to support the business practice they implemented. Even if they need the money, even if it doesnt hurt anyone. I will not support that. If you cant keep up with the cost of your game that isnt my fault, implement a different pay system, increase the game cost, make new cosmetics payed for idc, but the way they did it was not the way.
